abstract.p: Study abroad is becoming integral part of college curriculum, with some American colleges requiring students to do coursework in another country; about 206,000 students participated in foreign study programs in 2004-2005; chart shows top 20 countries and number of students who studied in each (special section, Education Life) (S)

block.p: IN the global age, study abroad is becoming a more integrated part of the curriculum. Some American colleges are even requiring that students travel to another country for coursework.

This academic year, Yale's School of Management restructured its curriculum and now requires M.B.A. candidates to do intensive study outside the country. Goucher College, in Baltimore, began a new liberal education curriculum this school year that makes study abroad mandatory. Each student gets a $1,200 voucher to offset costs.

This academic year, Yale's School of Management restructured its curriculum and now requires M.B.A. candidates to do intensive study outside the country. Goucher College, in Baltimore, began a new liberal education curriculum this school year that makes study abroad mandatory. Each student gets a $1,200 voucher to offset costs.

About 206,000 students participated in foreign study programs in 2004-5, according to the latest report from the Institute of International Education. Released in November, it shows that Europe continued to attract the most American college students, but China had the biggest jump: 35 percent more students went there than the previous year.
